bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, July 13, 1938

div1.p: Hench comments on the film “Yellow Jack.” He defends Kissinger and proposes further investigations of the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John J. Moran, July 13, 1938
div1.opener:
July 13, 1938
Mr. John J. Moran
c/o Cia. Sunoco de Cuba, S. A.
Avenida Menocal Nos. 455-457
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I would indeed like to be with you when you see the movie “Yellow Jack.”
I think you will criticize it as did Mr. Kissinger. I saw it recently here, and
unfortunately they put too much comedy in it, and there were only a few places where
it was adequately dramatized with sufficient dignity. I read somewhere a story of
Montgomery's reactions to this movie. Apparently, he and the other actors were more
depressed than stimulated by the serious nature of the play and whenever they could,
tried to relieve their feelings by clowning. It seems to me that this spirit was
also that of the producers. In trying to relieve the dramatic situations, they
“over-relieved” them. Nevertheless, it was an interesting movie, even if not too
accurate.

You will be interested to know that we invited Kissinger up here to speak
before an association here interested in medical research. He gave us a very inter-
esting talk, and repeatedly stated that it was to be understood that whatever he
had done, had been done also by you. He spoke frequently of you with the highest
regard. He said that he wished he had had your education, said that you had come
from a very excellent family, and in every way spoke most kindly and most highly
of you. I think your friends have perhaps done Kissinger somewhat of an injustice.
Naturally, those movie people see a certain amount of publicity in having one of
the volunteers at their preview. You have the perception to know that although in
a sense these invitations are sincere, nevertheless the movie people use their
guests for advertising purposes. When they can't get you, they will use Kissinger.
One cannot blame Kissinger for relieving the monotony of his quiet existence by such
trips, nor for accepting the little extra money that he gets for doing it. He does
it in good faith himself. As a matter of fact, his faith is too good, and recently
he criticized the movies so frankly that he almost criticized himself out of his
invitation. Your friends do him an injustice if they suggest to you that Kissinger
steals the show. This is most assuredly not true. The strong part of the play is
that of Sergeant O'Hara, taken by Montgomery, who is acting your part. As a matter
of fact, if anyone should criticize, I should think that Kissinger's friends would
criticize. As I see it, no one should criticize. Although it is natural for one's
friends to come to his defense and natural for your friends to want to see you get
your due credit, the same holds true for Kissinger's friends. We in the medical
profession and posterity in general regard your contributions equally. You both
offered everything you had, and the matter of who got stung first or who got sick
first was in the hands of Fate, not in your hands, and had nothing to do with
heightening or lessening your own contribution. I sincerely hope that your well
meaning friends will not permit you to think, in the slightest way, ill of Kissinger.

It is unfortunate that you are so far away and that he is on hand,
but perhaps it is not unfortunate, for as you say, you do not enjoy these
experiences.

Incidentally, I have not yet received the photographs, and hope
they haven't been lost.

When Kissinger was here, I took the liberty of checking over the
story again. There are parts of the story that do not quite agree with yours
or with the record. This is natural, as the episode has been idealized by
time and details have been forgotten through the years. I am therefore post-
poning presentation of the story until I can spend considerable time and research
on it in order that it may be as accurate as possible. I hope that it will be
part his story and part your story, but it must agree in essence with the
facts as given by Reed himself. You will see it long before it is published.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
